subject: Cooking
title: The Chemistry of Tea Oxidation
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Chemistry of Tea Oxidation usable.

hook.text: Green tea and black tea start as the same leaf. The difference? Controlled damage that triggers oxidation.

buildup.text: When tea leaves are bruised or rolled, enzymes called polyphenol oxidases react with oxygen in the air.

discovery.text: Green tea is heated immediately to stop oxidation. Oolong is partially oxidized. Black tea is fully oxidized.

twist.text: The process isn't fermentation â€” despite being called that for centuries. True fermentation occurs only in pu-erh tea.

climax.text: Oxidation converts catechins (green tea's antioxidants) into theaflavins (black tea's bold flavor compounds).

punchline.text: Same leaf. Different damage. Completely different drink.

quiz.question: What process turns green tea leaves into black tea?
